title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) – The final score read 107-87, but the story of the night was written in the box score next to one name: Gary Payton. In a virtuoso performance that will be etched into Seattle SuperSonics lore, "The Glove" didn't just play defense; he orchestrated a one-man symphony, dismantling the Vancouver Grizzlies with a historic 47-point outburst.

From the opening tip, Payton was in a different gear. He sliced through the Grizzlies’ defense with a ruthless efficiency, scoring from every conceivable angle on the floor. His 47 points were not just a season-high; they were a statement, a career-defining explosion that left the KeyArena crowd in a state of perpetual roar. The Grizzlies, despite a valiant 20-point effort from Shareef Abdur-Rahim and a double-double from Bryant Reeves (15 points, 11 rebounds), had no answer for the onslaught.

While Payton’s scoring was the headline, his all-around genius was the subtext. He dished out 9 assists, setting up teammates like Detlef Schrempf (13 points) and Vin Baker (10 points) when the defense finally dared to collapse on him. He was the engine, the heart, and the soul of a Sonics team that operated with a palpable, Payton-fueled confidence.

The Grizzlies were simply overmatched by a force of nature. Their efforts, led by Abdur-Rahim’s smooth offensive game and Reeves’ work in the paint, were rendered secondary on a night dominated by one man’s brilliance. This was not merely a victory; it was a coronation. Gary Payton didn't just win a basketball game; he authored a masterpiece, a 47-point testament to his greatness that Seattle will not soon forget.
